item.title: Quick Tip: Timestamping bash history
item.description: Here’s a tiny little snippet that I have in my .bashrc which really comes in handy when trying to figure out what I did on a system when. One of the first things I do when (eek) building out or working on a one-off machine (or setting up a …
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Readable Nagios Log Timestamps
item.description:
If you’re like me and most humans, the Nagios logfile timestamp (a unix timestamp) isn’t terribly useful when trying to grep through the logs and correlate events: 

# head -2 nagios.log
[1350360000] LOG ROTATION: DAILY
[1350360000] LOG VERSION: 2.0

Here’s a nifty Perl one-liner that you …
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: Quick and Simple Timestamping of Debug Logs
item.description: I’ve been having some issues that may be Puppet-related. Unfortunately, Puppet (at least the old 0.25.4 client that I’m running) doesn’t timestamp the debug logs sent to stdout. I know it’s hanging somewhere, but I need concrete numbers to look at. Here’s …
item.dc:creator: admin

item.title: My Birthday!
item.description: I happened to be working with some timestamps today and noticed that we’re starting to get into territory like 1234094400. So, being the geek that I am, I wondered when we’d finally hit 1234567890. The answer is 2009-02-13T18:31:30-05:00, which happens to be 18:31:30 …
item.dc:creator: admin
